column4: when installing Ubuntu, and at the partitioning stage, whats the difference between "/" and "/boot" ?
/ ist the root partition, which means that root is mounted there
if you want to add a sepparate partition for your boot-files you can add a /boot partition
so I could use /boot for boot files, / for linux install and /home formy stuff?
so if I used /boot and /home all would be ok?
i use /boot for my boot files too (size 100MB)
so there would be no advantage to have /boot, /, and /home? I should just have / and /home?
advantage is if you want to use an exotic file system on / which isn't supported by grub
Ahh! all makeing sense now, thank you very much :-)
but if you are using ext3 there is nearly no advantage using a sepparate /boot paritition
yes I always use EXT3, as everything I learned about file systems seems to indicate that this is the best all round for average joe's like me :-)
